required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Pilot Efficacy and Implementation Study of the Strengths Intervention Project
clinical_study.official_title: A Pilot Efficacy and Implementation Study of the Strengths Intervention Project

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to test a strengths-based intervention to be delivered in a primary care setting with adolescents and a parent. Investigators want to find out if the intervention can help parents and teens communicate. Specifically Investigators want to see if they can help parents and teens identify and build teen's strengths. Half the dyads will receive the educational materials in conjunction with their teen's well-child visit, while the other half will receive usual care at the well-child visit and receive the educational materials at the end of the study. Additionally, Investigators expect that a strengths-based intervention may also impact adherence to treatment in youth with a chronic illness. As such, Investigators will include a subgroup of teenagers diagnosed with asthma in this study, to assess whether the strengths-based intervention that the Investigators developed has an impact on adherence.

detailed_description.textblock:
Recent research suggests that parents and adolescents report an interest in doctors facilitating increased parent-teen communication about teen strengths. However, little research focuses on how to address this need in a primary care setting. Content from subject matter experts along with data gathered from parents and teens were used to develop a novel strengths-based intervention to be tested in primary care.
The study intervention being examined is called the Strengths Intervention Project and includes a written pamphlet, a guided discussion activity, in-person/phone health coaching, and in-person or mailed health care provider endorsement and key messaging. Measures will be collected at baseline pre-intervention (T1), in clinic or over the phone at the time of the intervention (T2), approximately two weeks post-intervention (T3), and approximately 2 months post-intervention (T4). Daily diaries will also be utilized twice to gather data pre- and post- intervention. We will measure feasibility of clinic implementation of intervention, as well as influence of intervention on parent-teen communication and adolescent outcomes.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Treatment groups receive intervention and control groups receive usual care.

primary_outcome.description: 26 items (parents only); Likert scale (1= very unlikely; 7= very, very likely)
20 items (parent and teens); Likert scale (1= strongly disagree; 5= strongly agree)

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Confidence in exploring and using adolescent's strengths
primary_outcome.description: 15 items (parents and teens); Likert scale (1=strongly disagree; 5= strongly agree)
Feasibility will be demonstrated by consent rates ≥60%

primary_outcome.measure: Parent and adolescent acceptability of intervention materials
primary_outcome.description: Adolescent and parent acceptability ratings ≥80%. Investigators will also elicit open-ended feedback.

primary_outcome.measure: Parent and adolescent acceptability of intervention materials (additional)
primary_outcome.description: 2 items (parents and teens); Yes/No/Not sure and Likert scale (1=very likely; 5 very unlikely)
Provider acceptability ratings ≥80%. Investigators will also elicit open-ended feedback.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Psychological well-being using the Flourishing Scale
secondary_outcome.description: Measure of psychological well-being. 8 items (parents and teens). (Likert scale 1= Strongly disagree; 2= Disagree; 3= Slightly disagree; 4= Mixed or neither agree nor disagree; 5= Slightly agree; 6= Agree; 7= Strongly agree). Score will be summed for range of 8 (Strong Disagreement with all items) to 56 (Strong Agreement with items). High scores signify that respondents view themselves in positive terms in important areas of functioning.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Adherence to inhaled controller medication use
secondary_outcome.description: 2-items about adherence to inhaled controller medication use (parent and teen) will be assessed using the Visual analog scale (0-10).

arm_group.description: Will receive the "Build Your Teen's Strengths" educational pamphlet, health coaching sessions, and provider endorsement.
Will receive usual care at well-child visit.
Will receive the "Build Your Teen's Strengths" educational pamphlet, health coaching sessions, and provider endorsement.
Will receive usual care at well-child visit.

intervention.intervention_name: Build and Support Your Teen's Strengths
intervention.description: This is a clinic based psychoeducational intervention for adolescent patients and their parents to improve parent-teen communication about teen strengths. The intervention is designed, if possible, to coincide with the adolescent patients' well-child visits and consists of the following components: (1) In-person or over the phone orientation session with a trained health coach and parent, (2) Distribution of psychoeducational materials to the parent, (3) Endorsement and delivery of key messages from the health care provider, and (4) "Booster" phone call placed by the health coach.

criteria.textblock:
Adolescent Criteria:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Teens age 13 to 15 years at the time of their upcoming well-child visit
2. Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) primary care patient.
3. Scheduled for a well-child visit that parent and teen both plan to attend
4. Diagnosed with Asthma > year (asthma subgroup) Prescribed a controller medication year-round (asthma subgroup)
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Not fluent in written or spoken English
2. Attending a new patient well-child visit
3. Presence of developmental delay or pervasive developmental disorder that requires special education services
4. Psychiatric hospitalization of the adolescent in the past year
5. Participated in studies: CHOP IRB # 15-011732 and/or CHOP IRB # 17-013895
6. Adolescent has sibling enrolled in (IRB 18-014922)
Parent Criteria:
Inclusion Criteria:
1) Parent or legal guardian of a teen age 13 to 15 years at their upcoming well-child visit at a CHOP primary care practice
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Not fluent in written or spoken English
2. Participated in studies: CHOP IRB # 15-011732 and/or CHOP IRB # 17-013895

link.description: Force UPST. USPSTF A and B Recommendations. 2017
